id-00002.label: Back Row; DISATK melee; GRANTDISATK melee

text.p: If they investigate the well:
text.frame: DMJust beneath the water of the well, you find a pouch containing hundreds of small brass coins with a hole in the middle.

text.p: Sells all standard weapons from the SRD. Convert from GP to Gil by multiplying by 20. (15gp = 300 Gil)
Sells all standard armors and shields from the SRD. Convert from GP to Gil by multiplying by 20.
text.frame: DMThe White Magic shop is tended by a woman dressed in white robes with red trim called Rose.
text.p: She sells scrolls:

linklist.link: Scroll of Mass Cure Wounds (40,000 Gil)

text.frame: DMThe Black Magic shop is tended by a man in dark blue robes. All you can see of his face is two glowing yellow eyes from the darkness of his hood. His name is Vivi.
text.p: He also sells scrolls:
The item shop sells the following items:

text.frame: DMRetroguardia is a small hamlet, with an inn and a few shops. Houses for the tiny population are surprisingly absent.
text.p: Most NPCs are very shallow characters that simply repeat variations on a single line of dialog.
text.frame: WomanWelcome, Warriors of Lig... Oh! You're not them. Well, welcome to Retroguardia Town all the same.
GuardRetroguardia castle is to the north, you should you speak to King Edgar about getting home.
ManThe evil knight, Garland, is bringing in the monsters outside of town through a portal.
WomanThis town is safe from the monsters outside because of the protection from the castle.
GuardI've been sent from the castle to protect this town.
Old WomanYou're not the first group of adventurers to pass through this town. The warriors of light passed through a while ago. Something about saving the world.
Old ManDo you mind? I'm having a whiz back here. (cough) These two shops here sell magic scrolls. Great for spellcasters!

p.b: If the players try to talk to an NPC for the second time read the following, along with some small talk:

text.frame: DMThe people in this town seem to lack in-depth conversational skills.

text.p: Characters can spend the night in the inn for 100 Gil per person.
text.frame: DMThe party share a single room with a bed each. You fall to sleep as soon as your head hits the pillow. The night seems to be over in an instant, but you are well rested.

text.h: If the characters enter the shrine to investigate:
text.frame: PriestHello, Light Warriors! Please, feel free to use the shrine to pray. Please come back if you are ever in trouble.
text.h: If the characters enter the shrine with a dead party member:
text.frame: PriestI see they fell in battle. I will resurrect them.
text.p: The priest will perform an arcane ritual which has the effect of:
text.h: If a party member is poisoned or diseased:
text.frame: PriestI see you are poisoned. Allow me to help.
text.p: The priest will perform an arcane ritual which has the effect of:
text.h: If the party should ever fall...
text.p: You may wish for them to wake up here, the priest having resurrected them.
text.frame: PriestIt's lucky I got to you!
DMA central fountain, surrounded by trees, bubbles water pleasantly. Nearby a woman dressed in a dancer's dress pouts.
YunaI'm Yuna. I'd love to dance for you, but I lost my dancing shoes in the castle, dancing for the princess!
text.p: If asked how she knows the princess she blushes and says:
text.frame: Me and Princess Garnet are friends.
text.p: If the party should retrieve the dancer's shoes
text.frame: YunaThank you!
DMThe dancer dances her seductive dance around the fountain.
YunaLet me reward you!
DMShe kisses whomever returned the shoes on the cheek and drops a bag in to their hand.

text.p: Retroguardia Castle is home to King Edgar, his Queen Hilda and his daughter Princess Garnet.
text.frame: DMAs you enter the castle, the guards meet your eyes. But they do not stop you from entering or moving about the castle
GuardFeel free to explore the castle.
GuardIf you wish to speak with The King, it's up these stairs.
Hand-maidenIs there anything I can get you, sir knights? Food? Drink?
Hand-maidenKing Edgar is a good man and a fair ruler.
ScholarOur ancient books tell of men traveling from other worlds.
Old ManDo you kids know magic? I used to do a mean Cure spell back in the day.

text.p: Princess Garnet is in love with Yuna the Dancer girl from the town. She is more than happy to return her shoes if the party ask.

The guard outside, Steiner, is very protective of the princess and won't let the party inside without good reason. However, he is aware of her affection for Yuna and will stand aside if the players mention her.
text.frame: Princess GarnetOf course, thank you for returning them to her. Please ask her to come visit again, soon.

text.p: An old man stands guard outside the rooms, the doors are locked with normal locks that can be defeated by a good lock pick or knock spell. They can also be opened by the key, freely offered by King Edgar (see 3.3.)
The party are not pursued or penalized in any way for stealing the treasure.
When the party first approaches the rooms:
text.frame: Old ManThese rooms contain a lot of treasure you know!
DMThe old man promptly falls in to a deep sleep.
text.p: The old man is really asleep, but could still be awoken by noisy adventurers. If the old man catches them:
text.frame: Old ManTrying to nab the treasure are you? He-he. Move along now you little scamps.
DMOnce again, the old man falls to sleep.

text.p: One man guards the door and he is happy to let past any non-threatening person.
text.frame: GuardPlease speak to King Edgar, inside.
DMThe King sits at his throne, looking to the distance as if in deep thought. His Queen stands to his side.
text.p: King Edgar and Queen Hilda are friendly and charming. They are happy to help the party in any way they can. They offer the party a bit of sanity after dealing with one line responses from most NPCs. You should feel free to improvise extra dialog for them.
If they speak to Hilda:
text.frame: Queen HildaI am Queen Hilda. Welcome adventurers to our kingdom. I trust your visit has been a pleasant one?
text.p: If they speak to Edgar:
text.frame: King EdgarHail, Adventurers. I am Kind Edgar. You know I used to be an adventurer myself in my youth. How may I be of help?
text.p: If they ask about how they got here or how to get home:
text.frame: Queen HildaThe evil Knight, Garland, has been using the Master Portal to bring in monsters from other worlds. He must have sent you here by mistake. You must find the Master Portal if you have any hope of getting home.
text.p: If they ask about Garland or the Master Portal:
text.frame: King EdgarGarland used to be my right-hand man. But he stole the Master Portal and has taken it to his layer in the mountains, past the broken bridge.
text.p: If they ask for help with the Broken Bridge:
text.frame: Queen HildaThe bridge cannot be repaired, but I will ask Cid, our master inventor if he can help you. He will wait for you downstairs.
text.p: If they ask about Garnet:
text.frame: Queen HildaGarnet is our only child. Someday she will be Queen.
text.p: If they ask about Yuna or her shoes:
text.frame: King EdgarYuna is Princess Garnet's girlfriend. She's always leaving her stuff around the place.
text.p: If they ask for money or supplies, they offer the keys to the treasure rooms.
text.frame: King EdgarTake whatever you need and leave the keys with the old man outside.

text.p: If the party has been offered Cid's help by The King and Queen, they will find him on the way out of the castle.
Depending on the number of players in the party, you may wish to make Cid a non-combatant.
text.frame: CidSure, I'll help you get across the bridge! I've got a new invention that will help.
DMCid has joined the party!
text.p: If questioned about the nature of his invention, Cid is evasive.
text.frame: CidYou'll see when we get there!

text.p: Every now and then the party gets randomly attacked. The attacks seem to come from nowhere - with no warning at all. Don't forget to give Gil after battles.
Don't overdo the random encounters. The game is on a clock. I suggest doing an encounter:

list.li: Near the start of the game. (See 1.1.)
On the way to The Broken Bridge.
If they decide to wander past The Cave.
If they seek out an encounter. (Within reason. See 0.3.)

text.p: Depending where the encouter takes place you can also use the following battlebacks:
There are three minor side-quests available. Because time is short, you may wish to not play these side-quests at all. But if you've got time, Side Quests are a classic feature of JRPGs.
Players find the side-quests by approaching the applicable area on the overworld map.

The party have been transported to an strange world, filled with the tropes of turn-based JRPG games in general and Final Fantasy in particular. They must deal with the limitations of an 8-bit world, crawl a short dungeon and defeat the evil knight Garland in order to get back home.

This is a short comedy adventure, designed for a group around levels 5 - 7. It is supposed to be completed in a single sitting. The players shouldn't find the difficulty very challenging, the fun is in the silliness of the setting. It's designed to be slotted in to an existing campaign as a one-off special adventure.
Come up with your own way they get transported to this land. Maybe they get pulled in to a strange portal, maybe they fall down a rabbit hole. Whatever is appropriate for your campaign.
Retroguardia doesn't have a deep back-story or history. It doesn't need one. The world is intentionally very shallow to mimic the very early video-games of this type.
If you feel it needs fleshing out more, you can pull in ideas from JRPGs you have played.
There's a lot to do in one session: a village, a castle, an obstacle, a dungeon and a boss encounter. In order to get it all done, you are going to have to keep the pace of the adventure moving.
You can use the shallowness of the JRPG setting to help with this. Here are some tips:

list.li: Fights should be quick and easy. (With the exception of Garland.)
Other than a few key exceptions, most NPCs have little to say, simply repeating their assigned dialog in different ways.
If your players are really stuck, you can have an NPC break character to help them.
The world is bound by JRPG tropes, but the players are not. If they can think of a way to subvert the narrative that helps them jump ahead, let them do that. Play it to the comedy of it.
The story is very linear. But if the party wants to go "off the rails" let them! It will only get them to the ending faster.
Game going too quickly? Throw in some extra random encounters.

text.p: Enjoyed this short module? Questions, corrections or other feedback? You can contact me via twitter @JiFish.
Gil are tiny brass coins with a central hole. It is the currency of Retroguardia and even the monsters carry it. Shops refuse to accept other coins , even if they seem valuable.
For a DM's rule of thumb, 1 gp = 20 gil or 1 gil = 5 cp. Don't tell the players this conversion. Let them be confused.
Smart players can sell goods to shops to earn Gil. Really smart players might sell their gold coins to the weapons or armor shops for metal recycling.
After a fight, the party should find Gil amounting to around twice the XP gained.
Like Disney Bucks, Gil is practically worthless once the adventure ends. They might be able to sell it for 1 cp per Gil for the novelty or scrap - if they can find a buyer.
Players who know the games might try throwing Gil to do damage. In this adventure, 50 Gil thrown does 1 hp of damage. The Gil is not recoverable.
Once the players return home throwing the coins does nothing - with hilarious consequences.
The changes are designed to both speed up combat and reference classic JRPG battle systems.

list.li: All players and monsters are in attack range of each other.
This counts for spells too. Area spells will not hit friendly targets.
The disengage, dash and attack of opportunity actions are not used. The cover rule is also not needed.
During movement, players may only Change Rows or Run . See below.

text.frame: DMYou have entered a battle! What do you wish to do? ATTACK, MAGIC, USE, CHANGE ROW or RUN?
text.p: A successful DC 14 Dexterity check is required to run away. If a character runs away the are no longer considered in range to make or take any attack. They can rejoin the combat at any time with an action . If half the party has run away, the rest also escape the combat automatically.
While in the back row, all melee attack rolls made by or against that character are at disadvantage. Players may freely change between front and back row with their action.
You can use the following effect on players in the back row:

p.b: Back Row; DISATK melee; GRANTDISATK melee

text.p: Just like in a video-game, any character can read any scroll, regardless of the spells available to their class or even possessing spellcasting at all. You can indicate this to players when they see a scroll.
text.frame: DMOrdinarily, a scroll of this type would be unintelligible to you. However, strangely, not only can you read the scroll, you think you may be able to cast it!
text.p: To speed things up even more, consider these changes to initiative:

list.li: Roll initiative once at the start and keep that order for the the whole session. Give them advantage on the roll.
Players may choose an initiative below what they rolled. (Useful if they want a more optimal turn order.)
Start new combats with the player who was next due a turn in the last combat.

text.frame: DMThe bridge still partially stands, as if a great force - or perhaps sea-monster - has simply shorn through it. The remaining parts are fairly stable, but there is a gap of at least 500 feet. The angry water rages from below. One part of the missing section juts out like a giant boulder in the water below.
text.p: If the party has chocobos, they can fly the gap if fed a dead pepper:
text.frame: ChocoboKWHAAA!!
DMYou feed the dead pepper to the chocobo and it immediately takes to the sky!
text.p: If the party does not have dead peppers they might be able to convince the chocobos to fly with an Animal Handling check, DC 18.
text.frame: DMThe chocobo flies majestically over the gap. Well, as majestically as the lumbering bird can manage.
text.h: If Cid is with the party
text.frame: CidDon't worry folks! My portable peddle-powered airship'll get us across the gap!
DMCid begins to quickly construct an unstable looking device with all manner of chains and sprockets. The device has a propeller on the top and many sets of peddles.
text.p: If the party wish to try the device, have them all roll strength checks and sum the results.
If the number is satisfactory:
text.frame: DMThe improbable device sails smoothly across the gap in the bridge. You just make it to the other side, out of breath and amazed.
text.p: If the number is not satisfactory:
text.frame: DMThe improbable device lifts in to the air... then crashes in to heap where it reverts to the pile of junk from which it was built.
text.p: Everyone in party takes 1d6 bludgeoning damage from the fall. They must find another way across.
text.h: If the party decide to swim
text.p: Players familar with videogame tropes may correctly guess that that swimming won't damage their inventory. If they try this, you can optionally have them make athletics checks. Either way, they should get an encounter:
text.h: If the party head to the docks for a boat
text.p: See 4.1:
Allow the players to think up their own way to cross the 500 foot gap. If the solution is silly, all the better. They are playing in a world of computer-game logic after all.
Some suggestions:

list.li: Everybody tie the 50 foot of rope from all the adventure's kits together, then tie all the clothes and blankets to it to make an very unsturdy rope.
Create a crude raft from a nearby trees.
Collapse the rest of the bridge somehow and then use the wreckage as giant stepping stones.

id-00017.name: 0.3 When players try to break things

text.p: The party is being presented with a very strange scenario and one that is in many ways intentionally linear and limiting. It's pefectly normal for them to want to test the boundaries of this world to figure out what will and won't work in Retroguardia.

This story is supposed to not only be funny, but also fun . Maybe they want to indulge in a particularly ridiculous JRPG trope or show how the setting is broken in some way. So as far as you can indulge them, let them explore that.
But if they try to break things too much, here are some potenitally useful antidotes. These are only suggestions.
text.h: The party has found a get rich quick scheme or are grinding battles for Gil and XP.
text.p: The scenerio is designed to get Gil in to the hands of the players quickly. There's no fun in having a new currency if the players don't ever get enough to spend. So let them do it to a point. If things go too far, shopkeepers can run out of money to buy items and random encounters can stop:
text.frame: DMIt appears that your mighty battles have scared away all the monsters in this area!
text.h: The party question an NPC too much or try to make them break character.
text.p: Most NPCs are very shallow characters that simply repeat variations on a single line of dialog. If a player should push one too far, they might have an existential crisis:
text.frame: NPCOh my word, you're right! I'm nothing but a random NPC handing out dialog to passing adventurers! My life has no meaning! I don't even have stats! ARRRRGGGH!
DMThey run away in to the distance, continuing to scream.
text.h: They try to rob a shop or the gambling hut.
text.p: You might want to not let them do this. Ordinarily such actions could have serious consequences, but in this bubble world there wouldn't really be any.
text.frame: DMAmazingly, the 3ft. high counter-top seems to be unscalable.
text.h: They find a way to really break combat.
text.p: The new combat rules are very loose. A character may have an abillity that exploits them and removes all the challenge. Nerf or restrict them if they come up. Maybe that ability simply doesn't work under the strange rules of this world.
Combat is still designed to be very easy, so hopefully it's not too bitter a pill to swallow.

You should never need this. But if your players really will not stop trying to break stuff, or try to escape the scenario entirely, this could serve as a pointed reminder that this world does not work under the same rules as they are used to.
text.frame: DMThe world around you becomes strange and distorted. All sound freezes except a single note of music, without end. Everything becomes blocky - even more so than normal - and starts to flash rapid colors. Then everything goes black. A word enters your vision: "ERROR."
text.p: Reset the players to an earlier stage in the game. Don't take any progress away, but this is an opportunity to point them the right direction.

text.frame: DMYou pass through the frame of the Master Portal - a chill passing through your bodies as you do so. On the other side you find yourselves standing excatly when and where you left.
text.p: Potentially also add:
text.frame: DMYou feel much happier to be back in a semi-sane world.
text.p: Items obtained in Retroguardia can continue to work. They are already based on the 5e rules.
Gil is virtually worthless. They might be able to sell it for 1cp per Gil if they can find a buyer. (See 0.2)
These events seem pretty fantastic, even by the standards of most other settings. The party may have a hard time getting others to believe them.
You can end the session with:
text.frame: DMSomewhere, off in a distant and odd plane of existence hang the words: GAME OVER.

text.p: The dock to the south of the map is only useful once the party discovers Garland is past the broken bridge. If the party investigate beforehand:
text.frame: DMThis strange dock is merely a small paved area with moorings. No buildings or people are in sight. You can see distant ships on the horizon.
text.p: Otherwise:
text.frame: DMThis strange dock is merely a small paved area with moorings. No buildings are in sight.

DMA ship is docked here the nameplate reads "Syldra" and it flies the Jolly Roger. Clearly, these pirates do not feel the need to be subtle. A loud ruckus can be heard from deck. The pirates are clearly enjoying their grog.
text.p: The crew consists of Captain Faris and her six crew-men. Although Faris is a woman, she dresses and acts just like her male crew.
The pirates are friendly and welcoming. Faris offers bottles of foul-smelling grog to visitors. The grog does 1d4 damage if consumed. If not consumed, it eats through the bottom of the bottle.
text.frame: FarisJoin us! Get these people bottles of Grog! Now then, what brings heroes aboard my ship?
text.p: If asked, the pirates will ferry the party to wherver they'd like to go for the outrageous price of 10,000 Gil. Unlike shops, Faris is willing to accept gold or jewels for payment. 10,000 Gil = 500 gp.
text.frame: FarisMy fine crew will sail you anywhere on the map for the low fee of 10,000 Gil.
text.p: If Cid is present, he will comment on the excessive fee.
text.frame: Cid10,000 Gil! That's daylight robbery!
text.p: If defeated in combat, the pirates will carry the party for free. The pirates have no booty to loot. They already spent it all on grog.
In this side quest the party has a chance to gamble their hard earned Gil.
Biggs and Wedge have set up a game of chance here to make some money off passing adventurers. The odds are not good, but the party could obtain some rare items.
If interrogated, Biggs and Wedge will confess there is a very high chance of getting nothing (33%) and a very small chance of a rare item (2%)
text.frame: BiggsWelcome to the...
WedgeGambling Hut!
BiggsWin rare items!
WedgeWin nothing at all!
BiggsGive it a try!
WedgeOpen a box for 700 Gil!
Biggs & WedgeYou know you want to!
text.p: After each box is opened, the box is replaced and they are all shuffled.
If a party should manage to get the same Super Rare item twice, they have to re-roll. Biggs and Wedge only have one of each.
If the party attempts to attack Biggs and Wedge or steal the treasure, they will be surprised to find the 3 ft high counter is unscalable. (See 0.3)
If the players venture in to the desert, they will encounter the deadly Cactuar. There's no point in defeating the foe other than bragging rights and some XP.
Note that players can run from the Cactuar without a check... and they probably should.
You should hint:

list.li: The sea is too vast to sail.
The mountains are too tall to climb.
The eastern forest is to dense to pass.
The northern river is too rapid to cross.

text.p: If the players still try and make a good attempt, they will find an invisible, impassable wall blocking their path. Lazy video-game devs!

text.frame: DMAs you enter through the passage in the cliff-face you see a staircase leading down. The steps lead to a strange cave. The rocks glow with a orange light and are warm to the touch. Footprints indicate someone has entered recently.
text.p: If Cid is with the party add:
text.frame: CidWell, heroes. The time has come for me to depart. I wish you luck with your quest.
DMCid has left the party.

text.p: The chest contain one of each of the following packages:

text.frame: DMAs soon as you open the door you are ambushed by strange bat-like creatures. For some reason they keep repeating the word "Zubat, Zubat!"
text.p: During this battle, be sure to mention that the Zubats 'faint' rather than die when reduced to 0hp. The party does not find any Gil after this fight.
See the Confused Behavior table if a Zubat hits with it's confuse ray. Remove all confusion at the end of the fight.

p.b: The party does not find any Gil after this fight.

text.p: Garland has been driven mad by life in this mediocre, poorly built world. He desires nothing more than to escape in to the party's reality where he can be a true villain - not just the first level boss. He is making his final preparations to leave guarded by two skeletons. Unfortunately Garland is as two-dimensional as the world he wishes to escape.
text.frame: GarlandWho dares invade the layer of Garland, arbiter of the Master Portal?
text.p: If the party ask after the Master Portal:
text.frame: GarlandNo-one may see the Master Portal but I!
text.p: If the party mentions getting home and/or mention how they got here.
text.frame: GarlandPerfect! The Master Portal is finally attuned to world suitable for my escape. I shall leave this paper-thin facade behind and be re-born in your world!
text.p: Garland will spill his life-story with not too much prompting.
text.frame: GarlandI'm tired of this pathetic trope-ridden world. With it's perfect little royal family ruling over a land with a grand population of three dozen. Yes, I stole the Master Portal. To find my escape! I may have accidentally summoned a few monsters. But now I have a better world to conquer!
text.p: A fight is inevitable. Garland will refuse access to The Master Portal and continue to threaten their world. Even if the party is able to negotiate a deal, Garland will stab them in the back as soon as possible.
After defeating Garland, there is little time to waste, next door the portal is collapsing!
text.frame: DMYou hear several loud cracks, as if of thunder, coming from the unopened door to the west.

DMAs you enter the room you see a freestanding frame, similar to that of a mirror. However, instead of your reflections, you can see your own world on the other side of the Master Portal. The image is disrupted by large moving cracks, as if black lighting dancing across the image.
text.p: A successful Arcana or Intelligence check will reveal the portal is collapsing and the party does not have long to pass through back to their world.

If the party fail to enter the portal in time or something else goes wrong, there is another option. If they return the Master Portal's frame to Retroguardia Castle, Cid can figure out how to reopen it.
However, once opened he realizes the portal will collapse again at any minute.
text.frame: CMIt's unstable!! Best jump through now, I dunno if I can open it again!!
text.p: Probably don't strand them in Retroguadia forever.
You could homebrew an escape story for the start of the next session. Or use good old-fashioned deus ex machina - another JRPG trope.
None of the doors in the dungeon are locked - unless you have a character who can pick locks.
Every now and then the party gets randomly attacked. The attacks seem to come from nowhere.

You have a chance to tune the speed of your adventure at this point. If the game is running long, only have a single random encounter. If you need to fill up time, do as many as you need. JRPG dungeons are known for having high encounter rates, so this is in theme.
Ignore the "Water Breathing" trait and read the following:
text.frame: DMCuriously, the sharks seem unbothered by the complete lack of water in the cave and instead are swimming through the air.

text.p: After transporting your characters to this world (see 0. Introduction) you might want to start right off with a fight! This gives you a chance to introduce the changed combat mechanics (see 0.3.) and give them some Gil.

p.b: Don't forget to give the party 500 Gil after the battle.

text.p: After the fight, the party find themselves on the far south of the overworld map. A short walk from Retroguardia Town.
After the battle is won, the party is approached by the friendly moogle, Mog.
text.frame: MogAre you okay, Kupo?
MogI'm Mog, the traveling Moogle!
text.p: If the party should ask how they got here, or how to get home:
text.frame: MogI'm not sure, Kupo. Maybe someone is Retroguardia Town can help you?
MogKUPO!
text.p: After the conversation Mog will go his own way.

text.frame: DMYou enter a small grove in the forest. Three large yellow birds are here. They seem fairly tame.
text.p: Players can capture Chocobos with a successful Animal Handling check, DC 14. Or if they want to jump right on an Acrobatics check, DC 16.
A single chocobo can carry 2 riders. While riding a chocobo, the players will not be attacked. You may wish to hint at this by having them ride right past a random encounter.
5 minutes after dismounting a chocobo, it will return back here to the forest.
text.frame: ChocoboKwhaa!
ChocobosKwhaa!
text.p: Chocobos can also fly up to 1000 ft when fed a special kind of pepper called Dead Pepper. (See 4. The Broken Bridge.)
The following NPCs will offer the party some dead peppers if they mention chocobos:

list.li: Mog
Princess Garnet
Yuna
Any old man or lady
Weirdly, Garland. But it's probably a glitch and it happens way too late in the game anyway.

text.frame: Oh, you're interested in Chocobos? Here take these Dead Peppers. They say chocobos will do ANYTHING for a Dead Pepper.

text.p: Just before entering Garland's chamber, the party once again encounters Mog, the friendly Moogle.
text.frame: MogHello again, Kupo!
text.p: After briefly catching up, Mog will offer the party two choices:
text.frame: MogWould like you like to SAVE YOUR GAME or MOGSHOP?
text.p: If the party ask after MOGSHOP, Mog will sell the party any items available in the shops of Retroguardia Town. (See 2.1.)
Mog will be unable to explain what "SAVE YOUR GAME" means. If the party choose to do it:
text.frame: DMThe moogle freezes for 10 seconds.
MogYour game has been saved, Kupo!
text.p: If the party falls in the final battle with Garland, they should re-appear here. Garland however will still be damaged from the fight and won't be happy about the party "cheating."
text.frame: GarlandHey, no fair! How come I don't get a chance to heal up?

description.p: Using this item casts the spell Revivify on the target creature without providing any additional material components, but the Phoenix Down crumbles to dust. Neither spellcasting nor attunement is required to use this item.
The Phoenix Down is feathers from a phoenix wrapped in twine and blessed by a white mage.
Yuna's Dancing Shoes
You have resistance to poison damage type while wearing this ribbon in your hair.

id-00003.name: Ribbon
id-00003.nonidentified: A delicately made gold ring with a Amethyst setting.

description.p: This strange weapon is from another world. It has +2 to hit, but you only get your proficiency bonus for damage.

id-00004.name: Excalipoor
id-00004.nonidentified: The attention to detail and the materials used mark this weapon out as special.

description.p: Chocobos go crazy for this pepper.
Very spicy. Not recommended for non-chocobos!
Once per day, you may summon a Chocobo to carry you and another person.
The chocobo appears out of nowhere and runs away back to nowhere if left alone for 5 minutes (even if restrained.)
If the chocobo dies, the chocobo feather turns to dust.
The chocobo arrives and departs magically, but it is not a magical creature.
1/4" diameter cut and polished Garnet gemstone

id-00017.name: 0.3 When players try to break things

id-00001.desc: Cid makes two attacks with his spanner.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 2) bludgeoning damage.
id-00002.name: Spanner

id-00004.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d10 + 1) piercing damage.
id-00004.name: Heavy Crossbow

text.p: Cid is a genius inventor and ally of King Edgar.

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) piercing damage.
id-00001.name: Bite

id-00001.desc:
Enchantment L3
Casting Time: 1 action
Range: 90 feet
Duration: Concentration, up to 1 minute
This spell assaults and twists creatures' minds, spawning delusions and provoking uncontrolled action. One creature you can see must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw when you cast this spell or be affected by it.
An affected target can't take reactions and must roll a d10 at the start of each of its turns to determine its behavior for that turn. See: Confused Behavior (Retroguardia) table.
Confused Behavior ceases at the end of combat.
id-00001.name: Confuse Ray (3/Day)

id-00001.desc: The zubat can't use its blindsight while deafened.
id-00001.name: Echolocation

id-00002.desc: The zubat has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.
id-00002.name: Keen Hearing

id-00001.desc: Garland attacks with Excalipoor (if he still has it,) Ultima Weapon and Stardust Rod.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5ft., one target. Hit 14 (3d6 + 4) slashing damage.
id-00002.name: Ultima Weapon

id-00003.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5ft., one target. Hit 16 (4d6 + 3) bludgeoning damage.
id-00003.name: Stardust Rod

id-00004.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +9 to hit, reach 5ft., one target. Hit 1 slashing damage.\nAfter using this weapon Garland will say, "Blast this stupid thing!" and toss it aside.
id-00004.name: Excalipoor

id-00004.desc:
Evocation L3
Casting Time: 1 action
Range: Self (100-foot line)
Duration: Instantaneous
A stroke of lightning forming a line 100 feet long and 5 feet wide blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 8d6 lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.
At Higher Levels. 
When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.
id-00004.name: Thundara

id-00005.desc:
Evocation Cantrip
Casting Time: 1 action
Range: 120 feet
Duration: Instantaneous
You hurl a mote of fire at a creature or object within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes 1d10 fire damage. A flammable object hit by this spell ignites if it isn't being worn or carried.
This spell's damage increases by 1d10 when you reach 5th level (2d10), 11th level (3d10), and 17th level (4d10).
id-00005.name: Fire

id-00006.desc:
Evocation L4
Casting Time: 1 action
Range: 300 feet
Duration: Instantaneous
A hail of rock-hard ice pounds to the ground in a 20-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within range. Each creature in the cylinder must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 2d8 bludgeoning damage and 4d6 cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
Hailstones turn the storm's area of effect into difficult terrain until the end of your next turn.
At Higher Levels. 
When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the bludgeoning damage increases by 1d8 for each slot level above 4th.
id-00006.name: Blizzaga

id-00001.desc: Garland is a charisma spellcaster and can cast unlimited spells.
id-00001.name: Spellcaster

id-00002.desc: At some point during the battle Garland will announce: "You fools... this isn't even my final form!!" and change to a monsterous demonic appearance. This has no effect on stats or health.
id-00002.name: Final Form

id-00003.desc: Garland will always use his attacks in this order: Multiattack, Blizzaga, Fire, Multiattack, Thundara.
id-00003.name: Scripted Fight

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) slashing damage.
id-00001.name: Scimitar

id-00002.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) piercing damage.
id-00002.name: Shortbow

id-00001.desc: The goblin can take the Disengage or Hide action as a bonus action on each of its turns.
id-00001.name: Nimble Escape

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +2 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 8 (2d4 + 3) bludgeoning damage.
id-00001.name: Choco-Kick!

text.p: A large yellow bird, as big a horse. They are fairly tame even when wild and make willing mounts.

id-00001.desc: Can fly 1000 ft when feed a Dead Pepper
id-00001.name: Short-Range Flight

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (2d6 + 2) bludgeoning damage + 3 (1d6) acid damage.
id-00001.name: Pseudopod

id-00006.conditionimmunities: blinded, charmed, deafened, exhaustion, frightened, prone
id-00006.name: Ochre Jelly

id-00001.desc: When a jelly that is Medium or larger is subjected to lightning or slashing damage, it splits into two new jellies if it has at least 10 hit points. Each new jelly has hit points equal to half the original jelly's, rounded down. New jellies are one size smaller than the original jelly.
id-00001.name: Split

id-00006.senses: blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 8

id-00001.desc: The jelly can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.
id-00001.name: Amorphous

id-00002.desc: The jelly can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.
id-00002.name: Spider Climb

id-00001.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, range 80/320 ft. one target. Hit: 100 piercing damage. This damage cannot be reduced or negated.
id-00001.name: 100 Needles

id-00001.desc: Cactuar does not persue people fleeing battle.
id-00001.name: EZ-Flee

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 3) piercing damage, and the target must make a DC 11 Constitution saving throw, taking 9 (2d8) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hit points, the target is stable but poisoned for 1 hour, and paralyzed while poisoned in this way.
id-00001.name: Bite

id-00002.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, range 30 ft./60 ft., one creature. Hit: The target is restrained by webbing. As an action, the restrained target can make a DC 12 Strength check, bursting the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; hp 5; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage).
id-00002.name: Web (Recharge 5-6)

id-00008.name: Giant Spider
id-00008.senses: blindsight 10 ft., darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 10

id-00001.desc: The spider can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.
id-00001.name: Spider Climb

id-00002.desc: While in contact with a web, the spider knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.
id-00002.name: Web Sense

id-00003.desc: The spider ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.
id-00003.name: Web Walker

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) piercing damage.
id-00001.name: Shortsword

id-00002.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, range 80 ft./320 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d6 + 2) piercing damage.
id-00002.name: Shortbow

id-00009.languages: understands languages it knew in life but can't speak
id-00009.name: Skeleton

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 + 1) slashing damage.
id-00001.name: Scimitar

id-00002.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +3 to hit, range 80 ft./320 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d8 + 1) piercing damage.
id-00002.name: Light Crossbow

text.p: Bandits rove in gangs and are sometimes led by thugs, veterans, or spellcasters. Not all bandits are evil. Oppression, drought, disease, or famine can often drive otherwise honest folk to a life of banditry.

Pirates are bandits of the high seas. They might be freebooters interested only in treasure and murder, or they might be privateers sanctioned by the crown to attack and plunder an enemy nation's vessels.

id-00001.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d8 + 2) piercing damage.
id-00001.name: Bite

text.p: Reef sharks measure 6 to 10 feet long, and inhabit shallow waters and coral reefs.

id-00001.desc: The shark has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the shark's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.
id-00001.name: Pack Tactics

id-00002.desc: The shark can breathe only underwater.\nNote: Ignore this trait in "An 8-bit Adventure"
id-00002.name: Water Breathing

id-00001.desc: If Mog is below 99 HP, he can fade away and vanish - presumably teleporting to some safe place. He leaves with an angry "KUPO!!"
id-00001.name: Run Away

id-00001.desc: Mog cannot attack in any way. But he doesn't need to.
id-00001.name: Non-Combatant

id-00001.desc: The giant makes two greatclub attacks.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +8 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 18 (3d8 + 5) bludgeoning damage.
id-00002.name: Greatclub

id-00003.desc: Ranged Weapon Attack: +8 to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. Hit: 21 (3d10 + 5) bludgeoning damage.
id-00003.name: Rock

text.p: Hill giants are selfish, dimwitted brutes that hunt and raid in constant search of food. Their skins are tan from lives spent beneath the sun, and their weapons are uprooted trees and rocks pulled from the earth.

id-00001.desc: Faris makes three melee attacks: two with her scimitar and one with her dagger. Or Faris makes two ranged attacks with her daggers.
id-00001.name: Multiattack

id-00002.desc: Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) slashing damage.
id-00002.name: Scimitar

id-00003.desc: Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) piercing damage.
id-00003.name: Dagger

id-00001.desc: Faris adds 2 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, she must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.
id-00001.name: Parry

text.p: It takes a strong personality, ruthless cunning, and a silver tongue to keep a gang of bandits in line. The bandit captain has these qualities in spades.

In addition to managing a crew of selfish malcontents, the pirate captain is a variation of the bandit captain, with a ship to protect and command. To keep the crew in line, the captain must mete out rewards and punishment on a regular basis.

More than treasure, a bandit captain or pirate captain craves infamy. A prisoner who appeals to the captain's vanity or ego is more likely to be treated fairly than a prisoner who does not or claims not to know anything of the captain's colorful reputation.

id-00001.description: Random Encounter table for Retroguardia Overworld
id-00001.name: Overworld Encounter Table

id-00002.description: Random Encounter table for Retroguardia Dungeon
id-00002.name: Dungeon Encounter Table

id-00003.description: Table to determine what a player gets after paying.
id-00003.name: Gambling Hut Winnings Table

notes.p: Roll on this table to determine targets behavior

id-00001.result: The creature snaps out of confusion.
The creature can not move or take actions this turn.
The creature must use its action to make a melee attack against a random target in reach.
The creature can act and move normally.
The creature must use its action to make a melee attack against itself.

description.p: Yuna' Dancing Shoes
A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains 2d4 + 2 hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.
A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains 2d4 + 2 hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.
A shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 2. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.

Using this item casts the spell Revivify on the target creature without providing any additional material components, but the Phoenix Down crumbles to dust. Neither spellcasting nor attument is required to use this item.
The Phoenix Down is wrapped feathers from a phoenix wrapped in twine and blessed by a white mage.
You have resistance to poison damage type while wearing this ribbon in your hair.

id-00001.name: Ribbon
id-00001.nonidentified: A delicately made gold ring with a Amethyst setting.

description.p: This strange weapon is from another world. It has +2 to hit, but you only get your proficiency bonus for damage.

id-00002.name: Excalipoor
id-00002.nonidentified: The attention to detail and the materials used mark this weapon out as special.

description.p: Chocobos go crazy for this pepper.
Very spicy. Not recommended for non-chocobos!

Using this item casts the spell Revivify on the target creature without providing any additional material components, but the Phoenix Down crumbles to dust. Neither spellcasting nor attunement is required to use this item.
The Phoenix Down is feathers from a phoenix wrapped in twine and blessed by a white mage.
Once per day, you may summon a Chocobo to carry you and another person.
The chocobo appears out of nowhere and runs away back to nowhere if left alone for 5 minutes (even if restrained.)
If the chocobo dies, the chocobo feather turns to dust.
The chocobo arrives and departs magically, but it is not a magical creature.
Chocobos go crazy for this pepper.
Very spicy. Not recommended for non-chocobos!
You have resistance to poison damage type while wearing this ribbon in your hair.

id-00001.name: Ribbon
id-00001.nonidentified: A delicately made gold ring with a Amethyst setting.

description.p: 1/4" diameter cut and polished Garnet gemstone
A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains 2d4 + 2 hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.
Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.
